questions:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with persistent diarrhoea after eating some undercooked chicken three days previously. On questioning, she has not been vomiting but has some mild abdominal pain. She has not noticed any blood or mucus in their stool. An arterial blood gas is taken as part of their investigations.

What is the most likely disorder of acid-base balance seen on arterial blood gas?
notes:
The answer is a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. This woman has increased gastrointestinal loss of bicarbonate from prolonged diarrhoea. The increased loss of bicarbonate results in the loss of alkalotic ions, leaving the blood in an acidotic state. This is a metabolic acidosis as carbon dioxide plays no role in the pH state. It is a normal anion gap as acidosis is not a result of acidotic ion production, such as lactate, ketosis, or salicylate acid.

Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis is incorrect. We do not have any information in the question to indicate hypoventilation, so there is not an excess of carbon dioxide in the blood, meaning this cannot be a respiratory acidosis. The reasons for this being a metabolic acidosis are above.

Normal anion gap metabolic alkalosis is incorrect. There is an increased loss of alkaline bicarbonate ions from this woman's diarrhoea, so the resultant disturbance is acidosis, not alkalotic. This disturbance is metabolic as opposed to respiratory, as there is no irregularity in carbon dioxide regulation.

Raised anion gap metabolic acidosis is incorrect. Causes of a raised anion gap include lactic acidosis, uric acidosis and ketoacidosis. The anion gap is raised in these cases because there is an additional acidotic ion now present. In this scenario, the bicarbonate is excreted during persistent diarrhoea which is the cause of the acidosis and normal anion gap.

Raised anion gap metabolic alkalosis is incorrect. There is increased loss of bicarbonate from the woman's diarrhoea, which is alkaline, so the resultant disturbance is acidosis. There is no excess acid being produced in the body (eg. lactate or ketones), so the anion gap would not be raised in this patient.

The anion gap is raised in these cases because there is an additional acidotic ion now present. Raised anion gap metabolic alkalosis is incorrect. There is increased loss of bicarbonate from the woman's diarrhoea, which is alkaline, so the resultant disturbance is acidosis. There is no excess acid being produced in the body (eg. lactate or ketones), so the anion gap would not be raised in this patient.
title: Metabolic acidosis
body:
Metabolic acidosis is commonly classified according to the anion gap. This can be calculated by: (Na+ + K+) - (Cl- + HCO-3). If a question supplies the chloride level then this is often a clue that the anion gap should be calculated. The normal range = 10-18 mmol/L

Normal anion gap ( = hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis)
  • gastrointestinal bicarbonate loss:
    • prolonged diarrhoea: may also result in hypokalaemia
    • ureterosigmoidostomy
    • fistula
  • renal tubular acidosis
  • drugs: e.g. acetazolamide
  • ammonium chloride injection
  • Addison's disease

Raised anion gap
  • lactate:
    • shock
    • sepsis
    • hypoxia
  • ketones:
    • diabetic ketoacidosis
    • alcohol
  • urate: renal failure
  • acid poisoning: salicylates, methanol

Metabolic acidosis secondary to high lactate levels may be subdivided into two types:
  • lactic acidosis type A: sepsis, shock, hypoxia, burns
  • lactic acidosis type B: metformin
concept: Diarrhoea - normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
media:

Respiratory Therapy Zone - YouTube40
 
Anion Gap EXPLAINED
HippocraTV - YouTube262

3493.concept_text: Addison's disease causes a metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap

7206.concept_text: Diarrhoea - normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

9308.concept_text: Sepsis can cause a profound lactic acidosis

options: Start anticoagulation with a DOAC after 4 weeks
Start anticoagulation with a DOAC after 6 weeks
Start anticoagulation with a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) after 2 weeks
questions:
A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with an 8-hour history of dense left-sided hemiparesis. A CT head shows a hypodense region in the territory of the right middle cerebral artery and he is admitted to the hyper-acute stroke unit for further management and is treated with 300mg aspirin.

During his admission, an ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent p waves. The patient asks about reducing the risk of a future stroke.

What is the most appropriate management option?
notes:
Start anticoagulation with a DOAC after 2 weeks is correct. This patient has evidence of an ischaemic stroke given the clinical findings of left-sided dense hemiparesis and a hypodense region in the territory of the right middle cerebral artery. The irregularly irregular rhythm on the ECG with absent p waves is typical of atrial fibrillation. Before initiating anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation following an ischaemic stroke, clinicians must wait for a minimum of 2 weeks. This is due to the risk of haemorrhagic transformation in the area of ischaemia.

Lifelong aspirin is incorrect. This patient has had an ischaemic stroke secondary to atrial fibrillation and requires lifelong anticoagulation to reduce the risk of further strokes, aspirin is not sufficient as a monotherapeutic agent to reduce the risk of further strokes.

Lifelong clopidogrel is incorrect. Although this is the recommended agent for the secondary prevention of stroke, this patient also has a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation and in such cases, anticoagulation with a DOAC, such as apixaban, is preferred.

Start anticoagulation with apixaban after 4 weeks and 6 weeks is incorrect. It would be inappropriate as it increases the risk of atrial thrombus and subsequent thromboembolism.

title: Atrial fibrillation: post-stroke
body:
Atrial fibrillation is one of the key risk factors for ischaemic stroke. It is therefore very important to recognise and treat atrial fibrillation if it's identified in a patient following a stroke or transient ischaemic attack (TIA).

Management
  • following a stroke or TIA it is obviously important to exclude a haemorrhage before starting any anticoagulation or antiplatelet therapy
  • for longer-term stroke prevention, NICE recommend warfarin or a direct thrombin or factor Xa inhibitor
  • the timing of when to start depends on whether it is a TIA or stroke
    • following a TIA, anticoagulation for AF should start immediately once imaging has excluded haemorrhage
    • in acute stroke patients, in the absence of haemorrhage, anticoagulation therapy should be commenced after 2 weeks. Antiplatelet therapy should be given in the intervening period. If imaging shows a very large cerebral infarction then the initiation of anticoagulation should be delayed
concept: A patient with AF + an acute stroke (not haemorrhagic) should have anticoagulation therapy started two weeks after the event
links:
NICE1328
2021 Atrial fibrillation guidelines

9732.concept_text: If a patient with AF has a stroke or TIA, the anticoagulant of choice should be warfarin or a direct thrombin or factor Xa inhibitor

9733.concept_text: A patient with AF + an acute stroke (not haemorrhagic) should have anticoagulation therapy started two weeks after the event

theme: Young woman with symptoms after stopping sertraline abruptly
questions:
A 28-year-old woman presents to her GP with a 2-day history of diarrhoea, nausea, and headache. She feels 'shaky' and has noticed some tingling in her hands. She has a history of depression and was taking sertraline 50mg daily for the past 8 months. She ran out of her medication 5 days ago and has not taken any since. Her vital signs are normal and physical examination is unremarkable.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
notes:
SSRI discontinuation syndrome is the correct answer in this clinical scenario. This patient has abruptly stopped sertraline after 8 months of regular use, and is now presenting 5 days later with a constellation of symptoms highly characteristic of SSRI discontinuation. The key features supporting this diagnosis include the temporal relationship between stopping the medication and symptom onset (typically occurring within 2-5 days of cessation), and the specific symptom profile. The patient exhibits gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhoea and nausea), neurological symptoms (headache and paraesthesia in the hands), and general malaise ('shaky' feeling). These symptoms align perfectly with the recognised features of SSRI discontinuation syndrome, which include mood changes, restlessness, sleep disturbance, unsteadiness, sweating, gastrointestinal disturbance, and paraesthesia. Whilst sertraline has a moderate half-life compared to other SSRIs, abrupt cessation can still precipitate discontinuation symptoms. The normal vital signs and unremarkable physical examination help exclude other acute medical conditions. Management would involve restarting the SSRI and then gradually tapering over at least 4 weeks if discontinuation is still desired. This case highlights the importance of patient education about the need to continue medications and not to stop abruptly, as well as ensuring adequate prescription supplies to prevent unintentional discontinuation.

Serotonin syndrome is an incorrect answer as this condition occurs with excessive serotonergic activity, typically when SSRIs are combined with other serotonergic medications (such as MAOIs, triptans, or tramadol) or when doses are increased. The clinical features of serotonin syndrome include a triad of mental status changes (agitation, confusion), autonomic hyperactivity (hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis), and neuromuscular abnormalities (hyperreflexia, clonus, rigidity). This patient's vital signs are normal, which argues strongly against serotonin syndrome, as autonomic instability is a hallmark of this condition. Furthermore, the patient has stopped rather than started or increased serotonergic medication, making this diagnosis implausible. The timing is also wrong - serotonin syndrome typically develops within hours of the precipitating event (drug initiation, dose increase, or drug interaction), not days after stopping a medication. The symptoms described, particularly the paraesthesia and gastrointestinal upset without autonomic features, are much more consistent with discontinuation syndrome than serotonin excess.

Anxiety disorder relapse is a tempting distractor as this patient does have an underlying history of depression, and anxiety and depression commonly coexist. The 'shaky' feeling could potentially be attributed to anxiety, and patients with anxiety disorders can experience gastrointestinal symptoms. However, several features make this diagnosis less likely than SSRI discontinuation syndrome. Firstly, the acute onset of symptoms precisely 5 days after stopping medication, rather than a more gradual return of psychiatric symptoms, suggests a pharmacological rather than psychiatric aetiology. Secondly, the prominent physical symptoms, particularly the paraesthesia and diarrhoea, are not typical presenting features of anxiety relapse. Thirdly, anxiety relapse would typically occur over weeks to months after stopping an effective antidepressant, not within days. The patient was stable on sertraline for 8 months, suggesting good disease control. Whilst relapse is certainly a risk when stopping antidepressants (which is why gradual tapering and continued treatment for at least 6 months after remission is recommended), the acute timeframe and specific symptom constellation point more clearly to a discontinuation syndrome.

Irritable bowel syndrome is an implausible diagnosis in this acute presentation. IBS is a chronic functional gastrointestinal disorder characterised by recurrent abdominal pain associated with altered bowel habits (diarrhoea, constipation, or both), typically developing over months to years. The diagnosis requires symptoms to be present for at least 6 months, with pain occurring at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. This patient presents with an acute 2-day history, which is completely inconsistent with the chronic, relapsing-remitting nature of IBS. Furthermore, IBS does not explain the neurological symptoms (headache and paraesthesia) or the 'shaky' feeling. The temporal relationship with stopping sertraline is coincidental if this were IBS, which would be highly unlikely. Whilst SSRIs are sometimes used to treat IBS symptoms (particularly IBS with diarrhoea), the acute presentation following medication cessation makes this diagnosis untenable. The constellation of gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms occurring together shortly after stopping an SSRI is pathognomonic for discontinuation syndrome rather than a primary gastrointestinal disorder.

Viral labyrinthitis could superficially explain some of this patient's symptoms, particularly the 'shaky' feeling, which might represent unsteadiness or vertigo, and the nausea. Viral labyrinthitis typically presents with acute onset vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and balance problems, often following an upper respiratory tract infection. The headache could also potentially fit with this diagnosis. However, several key features make this diagnosis less likely. Firstly, there is no mention of true vertigo (a sensation of the room spinning) or hearing loss, which are cardinal features of labyrinthitis. The patient describes feeling 'shaky' rather than vertiginous, which is more consistent with general malaise. Secondly, viral labyrinthitis does not explain the paraesthesia in the hands or the diarrhoea. Thirdly, and most importantly, the temporal relationship with stopping sertraline 5 days ago provides a much more compelling explanation for the symptom complex. The combination of gastrointestinal, neurological, and general symptoms occurring precisely after SSRI cessation is highly specific for discontinuation syndrome. Whilst viral labyrinthitis is more plausible than some other distractors because it could explain the dizziness and nausea, the absence of typical vestibular symptoms and the presence of features unexplained by this diagnosis (particularly paraesthesia and the medication history) make it incorrect.

title: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors
body:
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are considered first-line treatment for the majority of patients with depression.
  • citalopram (although see below re: QT interval) and fluoxetine are currently the preferred SSRIs
  • sertraline is useful post myocardial infarction as there is more evidence for its safe use in this situation than other antidepressants
  • SSRIs should be used with caution in children and adolescents. Fluoxetine is the drug of choice when an antidepressant is indicated

Adverse effects
  • gastrointestinal symptoms are the most common side-effect
  • there is an increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding in patients taking SSRIs. A proton pump inhibitor should be prescribed if a patient is also taking a NSAID
  • patients should be counselled to be vigilant for increased anxiety and agitation after starting a SSRI
  • fluoxetine and paroxetine have a higher propensity for drug interactions

Citalopram and the QT interval
  • the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) released a warning on the use of citalopram in 2011
  • it advised that citalopram and escitalopram are associated with dose-dependent QT interval prolongation and should not be used in those with: congenital long QT syndrome; known pre-existing QT interval prolongation; or in combination with other medicines that prolong the QT interval
  • the maximum daily dose is now 40 mg for adults; 20 mg for patients older than 65 years; and 20 mg for those with hepatic impairment

Interactions
  • NSAIDs: NICE guidelines advise 'do not normally offer SSRIs', but if given co-prescribe a proton pump inhibitor
  • warfarin / heparin: NICE guidelines recommend avoiding SSRIs and considering mirtazapine
  • aspirin
  • triptans - increased risk of serotonin syndrome
  • monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) - increased risk of serotonin syndrome

Following the initiation of antidepressant therapy patients should normally be reviewed by a doctor after 2 weeks. For patients under the age of 25 years or at increased risk of suicide should be reviewed after 1 week. If a patient makes a good response to antidepressant therapy they should continue on treatment for at least 6 months after remission as this reduces the risk of relapse.

When stopping a SSRI the dose should be gradually reduced over a 4 week period (this is not necessary with fluoxetine). Paroxetine has a higher incidence of discontinuation symptoms.

Discontinuation symptoms
  • increased mood change
  • restlessness
  • difficulty sleeping
  • unsteadiness
  • sweating
  • gastrointestinal symptoms: pain, cramping, diarrhoea, vomiting
  • paraesthesia

SSRIs and pregnancy
- BNF says to weigh up benefits and risk when deciding whether to use in pregnancy.
- Use during the first trimester gives a small increased risk of congenital heart defects
- Use during the third trimester can result in persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn
- Paroxetine has an increased risk of congenital malformations, particularly in the first trimester
concept: Gastrointestinal side-effects such as diarrhoea are seen in SSRI discontinuation syndrome
links:
NICE3641
2022 Depression in adults: treatment and management

Speed Pharmacology - YouTube93
 
Antidepressants Pharmacology
Soton Brain Hub - YouTube35

1140.concept_text: SSRIs and MAOIs should never be combined as there is a risk of serotonin syndrome

1143.concept_text: Antidepressants should be continued for at least 6 months after remission of symptoms to decrease risk of relapse

1144.concept_text: Dizziness, electric shock sensations and anxiety are symptoms of SSRI discontinuation syndrome

2415.concept_text: Sertraline is the SSRI of choice post myocardial infarction

2684.concept_text: Paroxetine use in pregnancy - can lead to increased risk of congenital malformations

8279.concept_text: Gastrointestinal side-effects such as diarrhoea are seen in SSRI discontinuation syndrome

8281.concept_text: Triptans should be avoided in patients taking a SSRI

9510.concept_text: Citalopram is the most likely SSRI to lead to QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes

11945.concept_text: Patients ≤  25 years who have been started on an SSRI should be reviewed after 1 week

questions: A 36-year-old woman who is undergoing her first IVF cycle presents with abdominal pain. Which one of the following would be least consistent with a diagnosis of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome?
notes:
The correct answer is Jaundice. Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a complication that can occur in women undergoing in vitro fertilisation (IVF). It results from an excessive response to taking the medicines (gonadotropins) to stimulate the development of eggs in the ovaries. However, jaundice, which is a yellowing of the skin and eyes due to raised bilirubin levels, is not typically associated with OHSS. Jaundice may suggest hepatobiliary disease or haemolytic anaemia, which are unrelated to OHSS.

Thromboembolism is incorrect because it could be consistent with OHSS. Severe OHSS can cause blood clots to form in large veins - a condition known as thromboembolism. This occurs because high levels of oestrogen produced during IVF treatment can make blood more prone to clotting.

Clinical evidence of ascites would also be consistent with a diagnosis of OHSS. Ascites refers to the accumulation of fluid within the peritoneal cavity, and it's one of the key clinical features of moderate-to-severe OHSS. The increase in vascular permeability induced by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) leads to the leakage of fluid from ovarian capillaries into the peritoneal cavity.

Similarly, Oliguria, or low urine output, could be seen in severe cases of OHSS. This happens as a result of intravascular volume depletion due to fluid shift into third space compartments such as the peritoneal cavity (ascites), pleural space or pericardial space.

Finally, Vomiting can also occur in women with OHSS as part of a spectrum of gastrointestinal symptoms including nausea and abdominal bloating or discomfort. These symptoms are thought to be caused by distension and displacement of the gastrointestinal tract by enlarged ovaries and ascites.

title: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome
body:
Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a complication seen in some forms of infertility treatment. It is postulated that the presence of multiple luteinized cysts within the ovaries results in high levels of not only oestrogens and progesterone but also vasoactive substances such as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). This results in increased membrane permeability and loss of fluid from the intravascular compartment

Whilst it is rarely seen with clomifene therapy is more likely to be seen following gonadotropin or hCG treatment. Up to one third of women who are having IVF may experience a mild form of OHSS

The RCOG uses the following classification of OHSS

MildModerateSevereCritical
• Abdominal pain
• Abdominal bloating		• As for mild
• Nausea and vomiting
• Ultrasound evidence of ascites		• As for moderate
• Clinical evidence of ascites
• Oliguria
• Haematocrit > 45%
• Hypoproteinaemia		• As for severe
• Thromboembolism
• Acute respiratory distress syndrome
• Anuria
• Tense ascites
links:
RCOG21
2016 Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome guidelines

questions:
A 28-year-old woman who is 8 weeks pregnant comes for the booking review. She is keen to find out more about the anomaly scan as a friend of hers terminated the pregnancy after some abnormalities were found on the anomaly scan. The patient would like to know when is the earliest time she can have the anomaly scan.

When is the earliest time she can have the scan?
notes:
Anomaly scan is done at 18-20 + 6 weeks, hence the earliest time she can have the scan is 18 weeks.

The dating scan can be done at 8 weeks the earliest.

The nuchal scan can be done at 11 weeks the earliest

title: Antenatal care: timetable
body:
NICE issued guidelines on routine care for the healthy pregnant woman in March 2008. They recommend:
  • 10 antenatal visits in the first pregnancy if uncomplicated
  • 7 antenatal visits in subsequent pregnancies if uncomplicated
  • women do not need to be seen by a consultant if the pregnancy is uncomplicated

GestationPurpose of visit
8 - 12 weeks (ideally < 10 weeks)Booking visit
  • general information e.g. diet, alcohol, smoking, folic acid, vitamin D, antenatal classes
  • BP, urine dipstick, check BMI
Booking bloods/urine
  • FBC, blood group, rhesus status, red cell alloantibodies, haemoglobinopathies
  • hepatitis B, syphilis
  • HIV test is offered to all women
  • urine culture to detect asymptomatic bacteriuria
10 - 13+6 weeksEarly scan to confirm dates, exclude multiple pregnancy
11 - 13+6 weeksDown's syndrome screening including nuchal scan
16 weeksInformation on the anomaly and the blood results. If Hb < 11 g/dl consider iron
Routine care: BP and urine dipstick
18 - 20+6 weeksAnomaly scan
25 weeks (only if primip)Routine care: BP, urine dipstick, symphysis-fundal height (SFH)
28 weeksRoutine care: BP, urine dipstick, SFH
Second screen for anaemia and atypical red cell alloantibodies. If Hb < 10.5 g/dl consider iron
First dose of anti-D prophylaxis to rhesus negative women
31 weeks (only if primip)Routine care as above
34 weeksRoutine care as above
Second dose of anti-D prophylaxis to rhesus negative women*
Information on labour and birth plan
36 weeksRoutine care as above
Check presentation - offer external cephalic version if indicated
Information on breast feeding, vitamin K, 'baby-blues'
38 weeksRoutine care as above
40 weeks (only if primip)Routine care as above
Discussion about options for prolonged pregnancy
41 weeksRoutine care as above
Discuss labour plans and possibility of induction

*the evidence base suggests that there is little difference in the efficacy of single-dose (at 28 weeks) and double-dose regimes (at 28 & 34 weeks). For this reason the RCOG in 2011 advised that either regime could be used 'depending on local factors'
concept: Antenatal care: anomaly scan is done at 18-20 + 6 weeks
links:
NICE1613
2021 Antenatal care guidelines

8020.concept_text: Early scan to confirm dates - 10 - 13+6 weeks

options: Folic acid 400 mcg per day once pregnancy has been confirmed
Folic acid 1 mg per day once pregnancy has been confirmed
Folic acid 5 mg per day starting now
Folic acid 10 mg per day starting now
Folic acid 400 mcg per day starting now
questions: A 34-year-old female with a history of primary generalised epilepsy presents to her GP as she plans to start a family. She currently takes lamotrigine as monotherapy. What advice should be given regarding the prevention of neural tube defects?
notes:
The correct answer is that folic acid 5 mg per day should be started now. Women taking anti-epileptic medications, including lamotrigine, have an increased risk of having a baby with neural tube defects. The UK epilepsy guidelines recommend that all women with epilepsy who are planning pregnancy should take high-dose folic acid (5 mg daily) before conception and continue until the end of the first trimester. This higher dose is necessary because anti-epileptic drugs interfere with folate metabolism. Starting before conception is crucial as neural tube closure occurs very early in pregnancy, often before the woman knows she is pregnant.

Folic acid 400 mcg per day once pregnancy has been confirmed is incorrect because this is the standard dose recommended for women without risk factors, and waiting until pregnancy is confirmed would be too late to prevent neural tube defects, which develop in the first few weeks after conception.

Folic acid 1 mg per day once pregnancy has been confirmed is incorrect for the same reasons - the dose is insufficient for women on anti-epileptic medications, and starting after pregnancy confirmation would be too late to provide optimal protection.

Folic acid 10 mg per day starting now is incorrect because this dose is unnecessarily high and exceeds the recommended dose for women taking anti-epileptic medications. There is no evidence that doses higher than 5 mg provide additional benefit.

Folic acid 400 mcg per day starting now is incorrect because although the timing of starting before conception is appropriate, this is the standard dose recommended for women without risk factors and is insufficient for women taking anti-epileptic medications who require the higher 5 mg dose.

title: Epilepsy: pregnancy and breast feeding
body:
The risks of uncontrolled epilepsy during pregnancy generally outweigh the risks of medication to the fetus. All women thinking about becoming pregnant should be advised to take folic acid 5mg per day well before pregnancy to minimise the risk of neural tube defects. Around 1-2% of newborns born to non-epileptic mothers have congenital defects. This rises to 3-4% if the mother takes antiepileptic medication.

Other points
  • aim for monotherapy
  • there is no indication to monitor antiepileptic drug levels
  • sodium valproate: associated with neural tube defects
  • carbamazepine: often considered the least teratogenic of the older antiepileptics
  • phenytoin: associated with cleft palate
  • lamotrigine: studies to date suggest the rate of congenital malformations may be low. The dose of lamotrigine may need to be increased in pregnancy

Breast feeding is generally considered safe for mothers taking antiepileptics with the possible exception of the barbiturates

It is advised that pregnant women taking phenytoin are given vitamin K in the last month of pregnancy to prevent clotting disorders in the newborn

Sodium valproate

The November 2013 issue of the Drug Safety Update also carried a warning about new evidence showing a significant risk of neurodevelopmental delay in children following maternal use of sodium valproate.

The update concludes that sodium valproate should not be used during pregnancy and in women of childbearing age unless clearly necessary. Women of childbearing age should not start treatment without specialist neurological or psychiatric advice.
links:
SIGN76
2018 Diagnosis and management of epilepsy in adults


NICE106
2022 Epilepsy guidelines


Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists74
2016 Epilepsy in Pregnancy

669.concept_text: Breast feeding is acceptable with nearly all anti-epileptic drugs

options: Advise will spontaneously regress within 4-6 months
questions: A 17-year-old female originally from Nigeria presents due to a swelling around her earlobe. She had her ears pierced around three months ago and has noticed the gradual development of an erythematous swelling since. On examination a keloid scar is seen. What is the most appropriate management?
notes:
The most appropriate management for this patient with a keloid scar is to refer for intralesional triamcinolone. Intralesional corticosteroids, such as triamcinolone, are the first-line treatment for keloids according to UK guidelines. They work by reducing inflammation, collagen synthesis, and fibroblast proliferation, ultimately leading to a reduction in the size and appearance of the keloid. Multiple injections may be required at 4-6 week intervals.

Refer for intralesional diclofenac is not an appropriate option because intralesional diclofenac is not commonly used for treating keloids. Diclofenac is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can help reduce inflammation but does not have the same efficacy as corticosteroids in reducing collagen synthesis and fibroblast proliferation.

Advise no treatment is available is incorrect because there are several treatment options available for keloids, including intralesional corticosteroid injections, silicone gel sheeting, pressure therapy, cryotherapy, laser therapy, and surgical excision.

Advise will spontaneously regress within 4-6 months is also incorrect because although some hypertrophic scars may improve with time, keloids generally do not spontaneously regress and often require intervention.

Lastly, refer for intralesional sclerotherapy is not an appropriate option as sclerotherapy involves injecting a sclerosing agent into blood vessels or tissues to cause them to shrink or collapse. This method is more commonly used in treating varicose veins or vascular malformations rather than keloids.

This method is more commonly used in treating varicose veins or vascular malformations rather than keloids.
title: Keloid scars
body:
Keloid scars are tumour-like lesions that arise from the connective tissue of a scar and extend beyond the dimensions of the original wound

Predisposing factors
  • ethnicity: more common in people with dark skin
  • occur more commonly in young adults, rare in the elderly
  • common sites (in order of decreasing frequency): sternum, shoulder, neck, face, extensor surface of limbs, trunk

Keloid scars are less likely if incisions are made along relaxed skin tension lines*

Treatment
  • early keloids may be treated with intra-lesional steroids e.g. triamcinolone
  • excision is sometimes required but careful consideration needs to given to the potential to create further keloid scarring


*Langer lines were historically used to determine the optimal incision line. They were based on procedures done on cadavers but have been shown to produce worse cosmetic results than when following skin tension lines

384.concept_text: Keloid scars are most common on the sternum

11895.concept_text: Intra-lesional steroids may be a useful treatment for keloid scarring

questions:
A 72-year-old woman who takes bendroflumethiazide for hypertension is admitted to the Emergency Department. Admission bloods show the following:

Na+131 mmol/l
K+2.2 mmol/l
Urea3.1 mmol/l
Creatinine56 µmol/l
Glucose4.3 mmol/l

Which one of the following ECG features is most likely to be seen?
notes:
The correct answer is U waves. U waves are a characteristic ECG finding in hypokalaemia, which this patient has (K+ 2.2 mmol/l). U waves appear as small positive deflections following the T wave and are best seen in leads V2-V4. The patient's hypokalaemia is likely due to bendroflumethiazide, a thiazide diuretic known to cause potassium loss. Severe hypokalaemia (K+ <2.5 mmol/l) requires urgent correction due to the risk of life-threatening arrhythmias. Other ECG changes in hypokalaemia include T wave flattening, ST depression, and prominent U waves.

Short PR interval is incorrect. A short PR interval (<120ms) is typically seen in pre-excitation syndromes like Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, where there is an accessory pathway between the atria and ventricles. It is not associated with hypokalaemia.

Short QT interval is incorrect. A short QT interval is a rare genetic condition associated with an increased risk of sudden cardiac death. Hypokalaemia typically causes QT interval prolongation rather than shortening.

Delta waves is incorrect. Delta waves are the characteristic slurred upstroke of the QRS complex seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, occurring in conjunction with a short PR interval. They are not associated with electrolyte disturbances.

J waves is incorrect. J waves (or Osborn waves) are positive deflections occurring at the J point (the junction between the QRS complex and ST segment). They are typically seen in hypothermia and are not associated with hypokalaemia.

title: ECG: hypokalaemia
body:
ECG features of hypokalaemia
  • U waves
  • small or absent T waves (occasionally inversion)
  • prolong PR interval
  • ST depression
  • long QT


In Hypokalaemia, U have no Pot and no T, but a long PR and a long QT
links:
Life in the Fast Lane5811
ECG: Hypokalaemia changes

questions:
A 12-year-old girl presents with a two-day history of an itchy rash over her whole body associated with a low-grade pyrexia:

© Image used on license from DermNet NZ

Which one of the following complications is least likely to occur?
notes: Dilated cardiomyopathy is not an established complication of chickenpox, unlike the other four options.
question:
A 12-year-old girl presents with a two-day history of an itchy rash over her whole body associated with a low-grade pyrexia:

© Image used on license from DermNet NZ

Which one of the following complications is least likely to occur?
question_notes: Dilated cardiomyopathy is not an established complication of chickenpox, unlike the other four options.
title: Chickenpox
body:
Chickenpox is caused by primary infection with varicella zoster virus. Shingles is a reactivation of the dormant virus in dorsal root ganglion

Chickenpox is highly infectious
  • spread via the respiratory route
  • can be caught from someone with shingles
  • infectivity = 4 days before rash, until 5 days after the rash first appeared*
  • incubation period = 10-21 days

Clinical features (tend to be more severe in older children/adults)
  • fever initially
  • itchy, rash starting on head/trunk before spreading. Initially macular then papular then vesicular
  • systemic upset is usually mild

Management is supportive
  • keep cool, trim nails
  • calamine lotion
  • school exclusion: NICE state the following: Advise that the most infectious period is 1-2 days before the rash appears, but infectivity continues until all the lesions are dry and have crusted over (usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash).
  • immunocompromised patients and newborns with peripartum exposure should receive varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG). If chickenpox develops then IV aciclovir should be considered

A common complication is secondary bacterial infection of the lesions
  • NSAIDs may increase this risk
  • whilst this commonly may manifest as a single infected lesion/small area of cellulitis, in a small number of patients invasive group A streptococcal soft tissue infections may occur resulting in necrotizing fasciitis

Rare complications include
  • pneumonia
  • encephalitis (cerebellar involvement may be seen)
  • disseminated haemorrhagic chickenpox
  • arthritis, nephritis and pancreatitis may very rarely be seen
links:
Public Health England65
Chapter 9: managing specific infectious diseases


Greenbook85
Varicella
media:
Varicella zoster virus
Osmosis - YouTube05

questions:
A 62-year-old woman with a history of bipolar affective disorder, hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to her GP with increasing lethargy and intermittent mild ataxia over the past week. She is taking lithium, metformin and ramipril. Six weeks ago, amlodipine was switched to indapamide for better blood pressure control. She denies vomiting or diarrhoea but mentions drinking less water due to reduced thirst recently. On examination she is alert, afebrile and oriented; neurological examination reveals a coarse tremor but no focal deficits. Laboratory investigations are as follows:

Lithium1.4 mmol/L(0.4 - 1.0)
Na+138 mmol/L(135 - 145)
Creatinine104 µmol/L(55 - 120)
Urea7.5 mmol/L(2.0 - 7.0)

Which factor most likely accounts for her current findings?
notes:
Recent indapamide initiation is the most likely precipitant in this scenario. Thiazide and thiazide-like diuretics such as indapamide reduce renal clearance of lithium by promoting sodium loss in the distal tubule, leading to compensatory reabsorption of lithium in the proximal tubule—thus raising serum lithium concentrations even if the dose remains unchanged. The temporal relationship between switching antihypertensive therapy from amlodipine (a calcium channel blocker that does not affect lithium) to indapamide six weeks prior, together with new onset symptoms and a raised lithium level above therapeutic range (but not grossly toxic), strongly supports this mechanism over other plausible causes.

Reduced oral fluid intake could theoretically contribute to mild dehydration and subsequent increased lithium levels due to decreased renal perfusion; however, there is no evidence of significant volume depletion on examination or marked prerenal changes biochemically (urea only marginally elevated). Her clinical presentation also lacks features like hypotension or tachycardia that would typically suggest hypovolaemia as the main cause.

ACE inhibitor therapy, while capable of impairing renal excretion of lithium and thus raising its concentration, has been ongoing rather than newly started or adjusted according to the scenario described—making it less temporally associated with symptom onset compared to recent thiazide initiation.

Chronic lithium accumulation can occur insidiously in elderly patients or those with chronic kidney disease; however, this patient’s creatinine remains within normal limits for her age and there is a clear recent change in medication more temporally linked with symptom development—making an acute-on-chronic process much less likely here.

Progression of diabetic nephropathy might be considered given her diabetes history; yet her renal function tests do not show significant deterioration compared to previous values implied by ongoing ramipril use without adjustment nor proteinuria/other signs suggesting acute worsening—all making this explanation less convincing than drug-induced reduction in lithium clearance.

title: Lithium toxicity
body:
Lithium is a mood stabilising drug used most commonly prophylactically in bipolar disorder but also as an adjunct in refractory depression. It has a very narrow therapeutic range (0.4-1.0 mmol/L) and a long plasma half-life being excreted primarily by the kidneys. Lithium toxicity generally occurs following concentrations > 1.5 mmol/L.

Toxicity may be precipitated by:
  • dehydration
  • renal failure
  • drugs: diuretics (especially thiazides), ACE inhibitors/angiotensin II receptor blockers, NSAIDs and metronidazole.

Features of toxicity
  • coarse tremor (a fine tremor is seen in therapeutic levels)
  • hyperreflexia
  • acute confusion
  • polyuria
  • seizure
  • coma

Management
  • mild-moderate toxicity may respond to volume resuscitation with normal saline
    • IV fluids with isotonic saline, until euvolemic, then typically twice maintenance rate
    • monitor serum sodium closely (every 4 hours with serial lithium concentrations) if there is a concern about lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • haemodialysis may be needed in severe toxicity
  • sodium bicarbonate is sometimes used but there is limited evidence to support this
    • by increasing the alkalinity of the urine it promotes lithium excretion
concept: Lithium toxicity can be precipitated by thiazides

2773.concept_text: Lithium toxicity can be precipitated by thiazides

9911.concept_text: Lithium toxicity can be precipitated by NSAIDs

10023.concept_text: Diarrhoea, vomiting, abdominal pain, coarse tremor, weakness, seizures, muscle twitches and blurred vision are among the signs and symptoms of lithium toxicity
